title: DevOps Principles
content:
DevOps is a set of practices that combines software development (Dev) and IT operations (Ops). It aims to shorten the systems development life cycle and provide continuous delivery with high software quality. DevOps is complementary with Agile software development; several DevOps aspects came from Agile methodology.

Core Principles (The Three Ways):
1. The First Way (Systems Thinking): Emphasizes the performance of the entire system, as opposed to the performance of a specific silo of work or department. It focuses on the flow of work from Development to Operations to the customer.
2. The Second Way (Amplify Feedback Loops): Creates right-to-left feedback loops. The goal is to shorten and amplify feedback loops so necessary corrections can be continually made.
3. The Third Way (Culture of Continual Experimentation and Learning): Fosters a culture of experimentation and learning, taking risks and learning from failure, and understanding that repetition and practice is the prerequisite to mastery.

Key Practices:
- Continuous Integration (CI): Developers regularly merge their code changes into a central repository, after which automated builds and tests are run.
- Continuous Delivery/Deployment (CD): Code changes are automatically built, tested, and prepared for a release to production. Continuous Deployment goes one step further by deploying every change to production automatically.
- Infrastructure as Code (IaC): Managing and provisioning infrastructure through code and software development techniques, such as version control and continuous integration.
- Monitoring and Logging: Capturing, categorizing, and analyzing data and logs generated by applications and infrastructure.
